original_data.question: Three days after induction chemotherapy, a 9-year-old boy is admitted to the hospital for fever and neutropenia. He was initially diagnosed with t(9;22)-positive acute T cell lymphoblastic leukemia following workup for fatigue and pancytopenia. He is fully conscious. His blood pressure is 110/65 mm Hg, temperature is 39.5°C (103.1°F), pulse is 98/min, and respiratory rate is 14/min. Physical examination including examination of the central venous catheter site shows no source of infection. Broad-spectrum antibiotics are initiated. Which of the following factors about this patient most strongly indicates a poor prognosis?

model_response:
Age, cytogenetics, and presentation at diagnosis have all been shown to be significant prognostic factors in pediatric ALL. Age is the single best answer of exclusion. Children younger than 1 year of age do very poorly, whereas older children have a better prognosis. Cytogenetics can predict for prognosis, with t(12;21) being good and t(9;22) being very bad. Presentation at diagnosis can also predict for prognosis, with those presenting in remission having a better prognosis. Fever and neutropenia, on the other hand, are worrisome for infection in a patient with immunosuppression due to chemotherapy. Infection in the setting of neutropenia is a very bad prognostic sign.

Answer: OPTION C IS CORRECT.</s><s>

question_entities.definition: The time for Earth to make a complete rotation on its axis; ordinarily divided into twenty-four hours, equal to 86 400 seconds. This also refers to a specific day.

Initial drug treatment designed to bring about REMISSION INDUCTION. It is typically a short-term and high-dose drug treatment that is followed by CONSOLIDATION CHEMOTHERAPY and then MAINTENANCE CHEMOTHERAPY.
Institutions with an organized medical staff which provide medical care to patients.
An abnormal elevation of body temperature, usually as a result of a pathologic process.
A decrease in the number of LEUKOCYTES in a blood sample below the normal range (LEUKOCYTE COUNT less than 4000).

The determination of the nature of a disease or condition, or the distinguishing of one disease or condition from another. Assessment may be made through physical examination, laboratory tests, or the likes. Computerized programs may be used to enhance the decision-making process.

A leukemia/lymphoma found predominately in children and young adults and characterized LYMPHADENOPATHY and THYMUS GLAND involvement. It most frequently presents as a lymphoma, but a leukemic progression in the bone marrow is common.
The state of weariness following a period of exertion, mental or physical, characterized by a decreased capacity for work and reduced efficiency to respond to stimuli.
Deficiency of all three cell elements of the blood, erythrocytes, leukocytes and platelets.
Sense of awareness of self and of the environment.
PRESSURE of the BLOOD on the ARTERIES and other BLOOD VESSELS.
The measure of the level of heat of a human or animal.
The rhythmical expansion and contraction of an ARTERY produced by waves of pressure caused by the ejection of BLOOD from the left ventricle of the HEART as it contracts.
The rate of breathing (inhalation and exhalation) measured within in a unit time, usually expressed as breaths per minute.
Systematic and thorough inspection of the patient for physical signs of disease or abnormality.
Systematic and thorough inspection of the patient for physical signs of disease or abnormality.
Catheters that are inserted into a large central vein such as a SUBCLAVIAN VEIN or FEMORAL VEIN.

An illness caused by an infectious agent or its toxins that occurs through the direct or indirect transmission of the infectious agent or its products from an infected individual or via an animal, vector or the inanimate environment to a susceptible animal or human host.
Plasmids encoding COLICINS.
Individuals participating in the health care system for the purpose of receiving therapeutic, diagnostic, or preventive procedures.
